title: What in the World Is GitHub Coding Agent?
content_html:
ğŸ¦„ You know, I've been ready to write this post for ages. This is the one thing that got me hooked on AI to begin with, and I'm still obsessed. But now that I'm here? I'm almost, almost too tired to even enjoy it. And because I'm a ride-or-die kind of person â€” either all in or over it yesterday â€” we're just going to dive headfirst into the shallow end. No holding back â€” I hope you're ready! ğŸ›Ÿ

Your 10-minute 101 to get you started with autonomous AI â°

Honestly? there's no way I can cover everything about GitHub Coding Agent in one go. So, for this post ğŸ‘‡, we're doing the "just enough to be dangerous" thing. I'll hit you with the absolute must-knows, show you how to get started (in 10 minutes or less), and hopefully, not put you to sleep in the process (or myself!).

My goal is to give you a "preview teaser" so you can go play, explore a bit, and maybe even tackle that hack time project you keep putting off. But whatever you do, please don't think this is your all-inclusive pass to go wild on production code. ğŸ«¡

Coding Agent â‰  Agent Mode ğŸ¤ª

Okay, let's get something straight right off the bat, because these names are just asking for trouble. Yes, they both have "GitHub" and "Agent" in the name. And yes, they're both powered by Claude Sonnet 4, but that's where the similarities stop. Agent Mode is for in-IDE use, a bit like a sidekick who waits for you to tell it what to do next. Coding Agent? It's the whole show â€” a full-on autonomous workflow that runs on its own dedicated VM.

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: Custom instructions and prompt techniques are the secret sauce here. This is true for any Gen-AI tool, but it's especially critical with Coding Agent, which will just keep guessing until it runs out of steam or thinks the job is done. Don't let it run wild without a map!

Don't worry, Coding Agent is designed with safety in mind. It's an incredibly contained, safe version of the "autonomous coding" experiment I ran on my own a while back. I spent 45 days arguing with a thing I wired up on my laptop, and I worked harder then than on any other project I've built before or since.

Why? Because I didn't want to just listen to what people were saying about AI â€” I needed to see it for myself.

ğŸ¦„ And that, my friends, is why I'm here volunteering as your guide. If you get stuck, hit me up! I've probably tried it that way plus three other insane ideas before I found one that mostly worked ğŸ™ƒ

Safety First, Chaos Second ğŸ›¡ï¸

I know, I know... I just spent a whole paragraph telling you how much I love this thing, and now I'm gonna give you the other half of the equation.

I'm all for pushing a new tool to its absolute limit, just to see what happens. It reminds me of my favorite Hunter S. Thompson quote â€” which I slightly mangled to get a SFW version â€” but the core truth remains:

When you find a new, beautiful wave, the tendency is to push it as far as you can.

So, how far can you push GitHub Coding Agent? Pretty far, but there are a few things you need to know first.

1. Just Because You Can, Doesn't Mean You Should

This tool can absolutely excel, but it requires the right prompt, instructions, and general setup. If you're looking to dive into some legacy code to see what's what, or maybe you want a safe playground to mess around in, then this is your guy!

But if you're thinking about using it to fix a production bug, especially when you're on a tight deadline, you probably (aka absolutely, most definitely) want to reconsider. Treat this as a "learn how this works" project, not a "throw it at a problem and hope" situation.

2. Your Prompt is Everything

The effectiveness of your instructions and prompt is multiplied exponentially by the complexity of your task. A great, well-thought-out set of instructions that you've carefully tweaked over weeks? Coding Agent will do fine. But if you spend 10 minutes throwing a few sentences together just to see what happens, don't be surprised when you come back to a haunted house where your beautiful little cottage of a codebase used to be.

ğŸ¦„ It is an agent and when an agent doesn't know something, they guess. That's just what they do. The only thing more dangerous than an AI off the rails and hallucinating is the fact that you just turned it loose on your code all by itself.

What It's Actually Good For âœ¨

After all those warnings, I need to make it crystal clear: this tool is not dangerous. It runs on its own virtual machine and executes safely within GitHub Actions. It has a limited environment and only has access to what you explicitly give it.

It always creates a new branch, which is a key safety feature. You can't get around it, even if you try. Trust me, I was annoyed, but the safety is worth it.

So what can you realistically use this for? Here are some of my favorite real-world use cases:

  • Documentation: Nothing has worked better for me than using Coding Agent to dive deep into a codebase and spit out test-ready use cases or a handful of detailed system architecture Mermaid diagrams. You set it loose, go get a coffee, and come back to 7-8 pages of detailed, well-researched use cases ready to be plugged in.
  • Testing: This one's a little controversial for a test-driven development purist like me, but... when you're on a deadline and you just need to get things done, you can write the code and have Coding Agent go write the tests. It's not a perfect solution, but a pull request with 28/30 passing tests is way better than one with zero tests at all. ğŸ¤«ğŸ«£
  • Project Planning: Got a big initiative coming up? Instead of spending a week flipping through pages of dead code to figure out how it used to work, you can have Coding Agent do the heavy lifting and print out a nifty little report when it's done.

How to Get Started in 5 Minutes or Less â±ï¸

In the interest of time and keeping this digestible, I'm going to give you the basics that will work 100% of the time. We'll dig in on some more tools next week.

GitHub has made this incredibly accessible now. You can find the new agents panel button on just about every page in GitHub: both on the home page and within any repository.

  1. Select the Repository and Base Branch: Choose the repo and the branch you want Coding Agent to work from. It will always create its own branch, so don't worry about selecting main (or a trunk-based development model) if that's your primary branch. I'm telling you, you can try to tell it not to create a branch, but it's not going to listen.

  2. Craft Your Prompt: This is not your typical conversational prompting. Coding Agent will keep guessing until it reaches what it considers to be "complete." Save yourself the headache and give it all the info up front.

  3. Submit Your Request: Every time you hit send, it's considered one premium request. This is why it's so important to be concise and provide all the context it needs upfront.

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: To save premium requests when reviewing Copilot's PR, go to the diff page and leave all your @copilot comments as pending. When you're ready, submit them all at once, and it will only cost you one request whether you leave two comments or 20.

A Final Warning About Responsibility ğŸ˜ˆ

Okay, one last thing. I have to let this sink in:

If it's your prompt, it's your code. Period.

If you go out and give a prompt to Copilot, ignore it for 30 minutes, do a half-hearted review, approve your own pull request, override the protection rules to push it to main, and then the codebase burns down... that's not Copilot's fault. That's your fault. Your prompt, your branch, your code, AI or not.

So, be aware, be smart, and please don't use this as an excuse to ignore the basics. Start small with documentation or tests, and work your way up.

Let's Get Real ğŸ¤¨

Have you tried GitHub Coding Agent yet? What are your thoughts? Are you all in or has it been a big nope so far? Drop your wins, fails, and horror stories in the comments below. Bonus points if you link a fun code review you've got to do for Copilot. ğŸ¤ª

This post was written by me + one suspiciously helpful robot (Gemini) + one robot firmly in the time-out corner (ChatGPT).

The Funeral ğŸ‘»

First, let me start this out by stating that OpenAI has officially buried the excuse that GPT canâ€™t code. We had the funeral over the weekend. All its friends were invited. Laid to rest. Cremation done. Trees planted. Memorial service complete.

Itâ€™s done â€” GPT-5 can code. Full stop.

There's no room for debate. No more hacks with pages of instructions or GPT hanging out on the sidelines because it's busy staring at the plan. OpenAI nailed it with an absolutely solid model.

Plus VS Code's release came with some more experimental features that turns the already-solid GPT-5 in to a â€œsend a prompt, make a plan, deep thinking, Implementation Specialist at your serviceâ€ experience. That being said, I still haven't had nearly enough time with the full model yet.

ğŸ¦„ Why, you ask? Because my brilliant self left my personal account logged in while working last week. That account? It's the cheap $10 one. I burned through all my premium requests before I even noticed. ğŸ«¥

So yes, GPT-5 (the real one) passed its early test runs beautifully â€” small to medium features, planning and implementation, no complaints. But the deep dive it deserves? Thatâ€™s still coming â€” stay tuned.

What was I doing instead of the GPT-5 deep dive? Playing the lead role in the horror story of Full House starring Kimmy Gibbler and the never-ending wall of text. ğŸ§—â€â™€ï¸ğŸ˜‘

Duct Tape, Please? ğŸ¤

GPT-5-Mini is not bad. Letâ€™s clear that up. For small, targeted context? For quick features? For implementing a clearly defined task with accuracy and precision? Itâ€™s great. Honestly. Kimmy Gibbler is a surprisingly solid coder.

But the output.
Oh. My. God. The. Output. ğŸ«¨ğŸ˜²ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’«

I'm talking about walls and walls of text. Waterfalls of â€œlook at me, I wrote a test!â€ status updates flooding my chat window like it's trying to set a world record. No, Kimmy, I donâ€™t need a play-by-play novella about the journey you took to create a three-line function.

ğŸ¦„ Sure â€” I started out at least trying to skim what it was saying. But my sanity didn't last long into that battle. Seriously, if I read another scroll of verbose rambling I might have retreated to some dark corner until next Tuesday.

The Standoff

At one point, it got so bad that I set up a stand-off. I told GPT something along the lines of, â€œGo check on that workflow. If it works, give me a checkmark. Thatâ€™s it. If you say anything else, Iâ€™m turning you off forever.â€

It complied. One lonely âœ… appeared.

ğŸ¦„ Victory? Maybe. For about thirty seconds. Then the rambling resumed. ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸

Hereâ€™s what I didnâ€™t realize at first: I had also turned on every single experimental preview feature in VS Code. Thatâ€™s my usual routine â€” release notes drop, Iâ€™m flipping switches left and right.

I thought I was enabling a neat little planning checklist feature. Which to be fair, I did do that... I also omitted its counterpart to internalize that chatter. Which meant the Mini chaos doubled â€” and nothing I added to the prompts or instructions made a bit of difference. ğŸ˜«

ğŸ¦„ I even tried to tame it with a new Principal Pragmatist chat mode. Didnâ€™t matter. Kimmy kept talking. Nonstop floods of text testing my sanity at every turn. Thanks, Kimmy.

Leatherface Joins the Party

GitHub Copilot is only part of the equation, though. Because just when I thought Iâ€™d found a rhythm there, here comes ChatGPT starring as Leatherface, chainsaw roaring, doing a happy dance all over my carefully constructed blog draft. Shredding paragraphs. Scattering virtual scraps across the room. Obliterating what had been a perfectly flowing system of prompts and edits.

ğŸ¦„ I mean, this post normally would have taken me a couple of hours. Instead, three days later, I'm still wrestling Leatherface for control of my own sentences.

Commands escalated. From firm. To censored. To questioning life choices. And finally, full-on ultimatum. I even took a few hours detour with Gemini â€” proof that I'm willing to go to war with an LLM over word count. (I'm also still losing that battle!)

The moral of the story? While GPT-5 is a great coder â€” it is more than terrible at creative writing. So, why do we have a single model replacement for 2 completely different problems, OpenAI?

Where We Are Now

So where does that leave things?

  • Mini: great in short bursts, but do not let her narrate. Especially not with every experimental feature flipped on. Else plan for duct tape.
  • ChatGPT: still a chainsaw in a library butchering my every attempt at creative writing.

And me? Still here. Still writing. Still dragging you through the chaos with me, because apparently this is how I process the fact that we had a funeral for â€œGPT canâ€™t codeâ€ and I celebrated it by duct-taping Gibbler and dodging Leatherface.

Sounds like a victory, right? Well, sort of. At least the tombstone is carved. ğŸ«¶ğŸ‘»

Stop tossing Copilot into the deep end without floaties! Write repo instructions, test them, tweak them, build them, repeat. Whether you use Microsoftâ€™s, Coding Agentâ€™s, or my Instructionalist, the goalâ€™s the same: keep Copilot coloring inside your lines.

Background

This post is one part personal call-out (I really need testers ğŸ™‹â€â™€ï¸) and one part sequel to my most-read post All Iâ€™ve Learned About GitHub Copilot Instructions (so far).

If you've never read it or if you missed some of the more recent updates (yes â€” I always try to go back and call out changes whenever GitHub or VS Code changes something), then go check out the basics first before getting too deep here. If you're already up to speed? Great â€” hop on in and I'll give you the grand tour! ğŸï¸

The original post still represents ~95% of how I handle custom instructions. I still use almost everything in it. But a few things have changed â€” new ways to get started, lessons learned from letting Copilot roam â€” on a leash â€” in enterprise codebases, and a sharper focus on making it write what you want instead of what it thinks you might have meant.

ğŸ¦„ Also, yes, shameless plug: I started an awesome-github-copilot repo. Itâ€™s still a WIP, but there are already a few gems in there. If youâ€™re willing to be a guinea pig ğŸ¹, reach out!

Why Repo Instructions Matter âš ï¸ğŸ‘‡

Letâ€™s set the scene. Youâ€™ve got a legacy monster app sitting in the corner. No one wants to touch it. And now a brand-new senior dev walks in the door. Would you say:

â€œHey, go refactor something. Good luck!â€

Of course not! But that's exactly what's happening every single time you drop Copilot in cold with zero guidance or direction about what you expect. It will produce something â€” and it will produce it confidently â€” and based entirely on your repoâ€™s worst patterns. Youâ€™ll get more code, faster, sure... but not at all better!

Plan an Up-Front 15 Min âŒšï¸

So instead of sending your golden senior developer off to the trenches on their first day, what if you just took 15 minutes with them? Explain why half the code is wired together like an escape room puzzle, which systems will blow up if they touch the wrong file, and why that java.io serialization is still hanging around after three Java upgrades.

Thatâ€™s exactly how you should treat Copilot.

And you'll see the exact same returns from Copilot as you would any well-trained developer who's capable of reading documentation and making the right call when it matters.

ğŸ¦„ Be aware: This is never going to be a "set-and-forget" system. It doesn't need constant care like a newborn (after a solid round of testing), but it's still gonna grow and change with your app. App changes = instructions change. Always!

Repo Instructions to the Rescue ğŸš¢ğŸ›Ÿ

Repo instructions are your chance to give Copilot a tour before it starts swinging a hammer. They work everywhere Copilot runs â€” IDE, GitHub.com, even mobile (according to the docs anyway). Put them in main, and suddenly everyone prompting Copilot is working from the same rules, style, and â€œdonâ€™t touchâ€ list.

If you're thinking about simply listing best coding practices just to show Copilot where commas go? You're not using them correctly. Start thinking of these files as the de facto onboarding for any senior dev and approach them with that level of info and let the auto-formatter handle the commas and new lines.

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: Copilot will naturally catch on, but a quick one-liner that says "Follow rules in [eslint.config.js](./eslint.config.js)" is generally all you need to have it start checking the lint commands automatically.

Start small and don't get the file get too bloated. If you have a set of similar instructions, you can always break them out into a custom instruction file apart from the primary version. Then use applyTo in the front-matter to define which files they should be applied to.

For example, you have specific database instructions that outline constraints or upcoming planned features and you want to start "forward thinking"? Put them in .github/instructions/database.instructions.md instead of the default file and add the applyTo. Any time Copilot references one of these DAO classes, these instructions would be attached automatically.

---
applyTo: src/main/java/dao/**/*
---

# My Custom Database Instructions

The Three Best Ways to Get Started

1. Microsoftâ€™s â€œGenerate Instructionsâ€ in VS Code (â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸)

When this first came out, Iâ€™ll be honest â€” I hated it. I mean, it was bad. â€œGo read the first line of every file in the repo, copy/paste them into a doc, and call it instructionsâ€ bad. It was like your coworker emailing you a Google search link instead of an actual answer.

But I have to be fair â€” itâ€™s better now. It actually reads your repo, finds the important stuff, maps out project structure, and even calls out workflows and automation. Still not perfect, but you could hand it to a new dev and they wouldnâ€™t immediately run screaming.

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: Let your formatter + linter handle style rules so you donâ€™t waste instruction space showing Copilot where commas go. Absolutely no one needs 14 examples of what JavaScript looks like in their instructions file.

How to run it:

ğŸ’» Expand for screenshots in VS Code for generating Microsoft repo instructions

In VS Code:

  1. Click the gear icon âš™ï¸ at the top of the chat window.
  2. Click Generate Instructions
  3. Let it run.
  4. Then, like any responsible repo owner, trim the fluff before committing.

Alternate:

  1. Press Ctrl+Shift+P / Cmd+Shift+P.
  2. Search Chat: Generate Workspace Instructions File.

2. Coding Agent (â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸Â½ â€“ creeping toward 4)

This oneâ€™s a little different â€” it runs on Claude Sonnet 4, and no, you donâ€™t get to change that. The upside? Claudeâ€™s got a good sense of architecture and implementation strategy, so itâ€™s a bit like asking the â€œbig pictureâ€ person on your team for a first draft. The downside? If you arenâ€™t specific, itâ€™ll start guessing... and you might get a fully stocked contributor guide when you really just wanted repo setup notes.

Coding Agent is also PR-safe â€” it always creates a separate branch. You could tell it â€œgo wild,â€ walk away, and it wouldnâ€™t touch your main branch without a pull request. Bonus â€” you can prompt it with a mini-series and as long as it fits in the single prompt, it will tackle your whole list for a single premium request.

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: The specifics here are key. Think of it like you're leading KT. What are all the important highlights that you'll need to get the basics across? If you're not sure, it's better to omit something than be wrong or mention a maybe that will force Copilot to guess on your behalf.

How to run it:

ğŸ’» Click for screenshots on GitHub.com for generating repo instructions with Coding Agent

At GitHub.com/Copilot:

  1. Go to GitHub.com/Copilot.
  2. Click Agents in the lefthand sidebar.
  3. Pick your repo + base branch (Copilot will still make its own branch from there).
  4. Prompt it: â€œGenerate custom repository instructions for this repoâ€ + any important specifics.

3. My â€œInstructionalistâ€ Chat Mode (â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸, with bias admitted)

Okay, yes, Iâ€™m biased. But this thing exists because I got tired of explaining â€” for the fourth or fifth time â€” why every repo should have good Copilot instructions.

Itâ€™s a Q&A where you (aka the person who actually knows the repo) fill in the stuff Copilot canâ€™t guess: your SLAs, the weird dependencies that no one touches, the â€œif X happens at 3:15 AM, restart Y or the whole system falls overâ€ kind of lore.

It writes from â€œwhere we want to be,â€ not â€œwhere we are,â€ and builds in things the other methods skip â€” anti-patterns, testing goals, deployment notes, even gentle nudges like â€œacknowledge uncertaintyâ€ when multiple solutions exist.

ğŸ“¢ Model note: This oneâ€™s running on GPT-4.1 too!

How to run it:

ğŸ’» Click for a quick video on loading custom chat modes in VS Code


Copy the chat mode:

  1. My repo is at github.com/anchildress1/awesome-github-copilot

  2. Find The Instructionalist chat mode and copy raw content

    âš ï¸ Careful! Don't grab docs by mistake. You're looking for the file that ends in .chatmode.md

  3. Create a new chat mode in VS Code and replace default with pasted Instructionalist

  4. Select custom mode from the dropdown

  5. Prompt Copilot to begin

    ğŸ¦„ Try something like Help me create repo instructions and give it time to scan your setup. Then answer as much as you can â€” Copilot will filter out what it doesn't need.

    ğŸ¤ This is a perfect time to try the Speech plugin, but check the delay setting first so it doesn't send before you're ready.

ğŸ¥ Check out Loading GitHub Copilot Chat Modes in VS Code on YouTube.

The Results ğŸ™

Microsoft in VS Code ğŸª¼

Microsoftâ€™s instructions were very structure-first. You get a â€œWelcome to this repositoryâ€ blurb at the top (which I left out in mine, because why?) and sections like Project Structure and Key Concepts. I was surprised that it even calls out the status badge system. Itâ€™s tidy and functional. It works.

ğŸ¦„ It also adds a short â€œhow to turn on custom instructionsâ€ note â€” which you shouldnâ€™t need, unless youâ€™ve gone in and toggled them off on purpose before.

Coding Agent via GitHub ğŸ§©

Coding Agentâ€™s version swaps the order around a bit and renames a few headers (although, I donâ€™t consider â€œstructureâ€ and â€œprinciplesâ€ to be interchangeable â€” so if you use this method, consider renaming that!) It skips the status badge part in the intro but circles back later with its own Status System section. You also get content guidelines, writing style notes, and real markdown link refs for internal docs (which is best practice).

But it also tries to sneak in a whole Contribution Guidelines section... which, letâ€™s be honest, belongs in a CONTRIBUTING.md, not in instructions for Copilot.

ğŸ¦„ This is not the first time Coding Agent has tried to add every possible document GitHub makes available during a PR. It seems to be wired into the fact that if you have a public repo, then you need all of these things to exist. I'm going to dig into this more and report back.

The Instructionalist Custom Chat Mode ğŸ“¢

My version ignores all of the â€œWelcomeâ€ and â€œStructureâ€ boilerplate and instead jumps straight into "Purpose" and "Value". It defines chat modes, prompts, and instructions in a way that makes Copilotâ€™s role more engaging and interactive. Copilot makes it clear these arenâ€™t just generic AI prompts â€” theyâ€™re curated for all stages of the dev process.

These donâ€™t explicitly call out the status badge system, but it's referenced in context. And you get extras you wonâ€™t see in the other two: "Maturity Level" (so Copilot knows if the project is actively maintained or just camping in test mode), "Dependencies on Other Systems", and, yes, the occasional bit of lore. ğŸ˜‡ Plus explicit anti-patterns and testing/deployment plans.

ğŸ¦„ I have to call out this is the only version that requires the user to participate up front. So naturally it takes longer to spin up. If you're asking me? Completely worth the trade off.

Final Answer? â‰ï¸

When you stack them side-by-side, you can see the philosophy differences right away:

  • Microsoft: Orient Copilot by describing the map (structure, files, concepts).
  • Coding Agent: Orient Copilot by describing the rules of the game (guidelines, principles, styles).
  • My Instructionalist: Orient Copilot by describing the playerâ€™s role (purpose, value, patterns, anti-patterns).

The truth? If you completely ignore the fact that I clearly think mine is the best (because of course I do), the ideal file is actually a hybrid. A little structure from Microsoft, a little guideline clarity from Coding Agent, and a little persona and context from The Instructionalist.

Every generated file is long, so donâ€™t be afraid to cut anything that's not adding obvious value. Save extras in a /future-review folder. Keep essentials in the main file, and for the love of your PR sanity â€” update them every time something changes!

âš ï¸ Seriously, y'all! Old instructions are just as dangerous as no instructions at all!

What Else Have You Tried?

Have you tried writing instructions by hand or generating your own with Copilot yet? Whether you go Microsoft, Coding Agent, my Instructionalist, some weird hybrid of all three, or something different entirely â€” I want to know what worked (and what exploded).

Drop your results, screenshots, or horror stories in the comments. Bonus points if you rate yours higher than mine. ğŸ˜›

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Built with AI

...but only after I gave it a proper tour, told it where the coffee machine was, and warned it about the zombie curse actively infecting LLC..

No Copilots were left unsupervised during the making of this post.

ğŸ¦„ I actually started a version of this post over a week ago, but instead ended up with So... This Was Just a Test - You Made It a Thing. And no â€“ I canâ€™t even begin to explain how I started writing about teamwork and ended up with a mostly-coherent explanation of my general thought process over the past 2 months...

Just trust the process â€“ sometimes I take the scenic route, but I promise Iâ€™ll get us there eventually. Plus, I always have fun on the way! ğŸ˜‡ğŸ‰ğŸˆ

Background ğŸ“

The original thought was "we never really learned how to do remote..." Not well anyway. My job is 100% remote with distributed teammates from the Pacific US to India. Weâ€™re a relatively small team â€” fewer than 10 devs â€” split into three different dev roles. But Iâ€™m regularly chatting with other teams and posting in random channels (mostly the AI ones â€” not surprised? ğŸ˜).

Since then, the original topic morphed thanks to a conversation with a friend, then expanded a little at work, and finally snowballed into a full-on get-it-out-of-my-system rant with my sister. Now? Iâ€™m sealing the deal with this post and moving on (metaphorically, anyway) ğŸª„âœ¨

The dream (and the reality that showed up)

For a lot of us, remote work was always the dream. Morning meetings in PJs (or the occasional stand-up in bed â€” âœ‹ guilty!), zero traffic, quiet when you need it, and the freedom to yell at the code as loud as you want without getting weird side-eyes. Best of all: SFW only applies if the mic is on. âœ¨ Pretty spectacular!

When COVID first hit, it was chaos:

  • Corporate jobs flipping to remote overnight.
  • Scrambling for tools to connect.
  • Bandwidth collapses when everyone in the house tried video calls at once

â˜ï¸ Or my personal back-to-DSL nightmare that never had a chance from the start...

We got through it, though. We basically went from â€œhow do I unmute this thing?â€ to running three apps, two VPNs, and a custom Slack bot before breakfast. We found new best practices. Some went back to the office and thrived there (ğŸ‘‹ to all my polar opposites), others stayed fully remote, but we all learned a little something along the way.

The "Generational Gap" Problem ğŸŒ

This isnâ€™t about age â€” itâ€™s the fundamental expectations at work that highlight certain stereotypes (for me, anyway). I'm talking about the generalized ones we deal with daily and are hard to navigate for everyone.

We're in the beginnings of what I call the Gen Zâ€“style of work: a focus on mental health, work-life balance, and meaningful projects that are about more than just a paycheck. We have health plans with mental health baked in by default, a push towards flexible schedules, more lenient maternity leave, and parental paid time off. Work supports personal projects and dedicated hack time for tinkering or learning new things that you're actually interested in.

The Boomer-era mindset is hard to leave behind, though â€” you know, the "work hard, stay late, forego overtime, do whatever it takes to get the job done, because the job provides for your family" version of success. The Baby Boomer generation officially ended in 1964, so it's well past time for the unattainable "always push harder" and "yes-man" mentality to stop. The problem? Most of us were raised with this model guiding the way. So, it takes a little more deliberate effort to let it go. ğŸ¤

ğŸ¦„ Yes â€” I looked it up. If you're like me and went for the calculator, that's exactly 61 years ago.

What this post is really about ğŸ¯

Remote teamwork isnâ€™t just being online at the same time or getting through stand-up in one piece. Itâ€™s about setting the right expectations â€” for yourself, for your teammates, and for everyone else who interacts with you. These next sections are the things I do daily to keep projects moving, avoid burnout, and make sure Iâ€™m not accidentally the reason someone elseâ€™s day gets derailed. ğŸš‚

So, whether you're a new dev, been at the job a while, or are just dev-adjacent â€” here's my simple list of impactful ways to manage your time across time zones, without disrupting your team in the process.

1. Your time is golden â±ï¸ğŸ¥‡

No one can do their best work when theyâ€™re exhausted, overworked, and stuck on a â€œfive-minute fixâ€ for four hours. Your calendar can save you from both burnout and rabbit holes â€” especially as you get promoted and meetings start eating into your dev time. If itâ€™s not scheduled from start to finish, youâ€™re probably underusing it.

  • Set and share your work hours. Whether youâ€™re 6 AMâ€“2 PM or 11 AMâ€“7 PM, make it visible in Outlook, Slack, and anywhere else your team interacts.

  • Be selective with meetings. Accept whatâ€™s essential, mark the â€œmaybesâ€ as tentative, and decline whatâ€™s not worth your time.

    ğŸ¦„ Got FOMO? Outlook has a setting to keep declined meetings visible so you don't need to worry about missing something.

  • Block recurring time for routine tasks. Email/Slack replies, code reviews, lunch (donâ€™t skip it else youâ€™ll end up eating chips over your keyboard and pretending it was a meal!). Group them in one or two daily slots instead of scattering them across the day.

  • Protect deep work time. Use your largest open blocks for development (that's why we're here, right?) If those time blocks are missing right now, then go out a week or two in the future and schedule them now, before your calendar fills up again.

  • End meetings early by default. If youâ€™re the organizer, set them to finish 5â€“10 minutes before the hour. That buffer is gold for clearing quick messages before diving back in!

    ğŸ³ Or, if youâ€™re like me, raiding the cabinets for something that will cook itself in under a minute.

The goal here isnâ€™t to be rigid â€” itâ€™s to set boundaries. Once your workday is over, shut it down. Literally! Save your spot, leave a note-to-self for tomorrow, and log off without the guilt and go do literally anything else!

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: Have trouble walking away with things still to do? At least activate your built-in selective-ignore feature (aka status = away) at quitting time, and respond only to messages that truly canâ€™t wait until tomorrow.

2. Everyone elseâ€™s time is golden, too ğŸ«¶

Itâ€™s the cat-herding golden rule â€” you canâ€™t demand respect for your own schedule and ignore everyone elseâ€™s.

  • Schedule messages when possible. If the recipient isnâ€™t online and itâ€™s not urgent, time it for their working hours.

    ğŸ’¬ Bonus: you also avoid becoming the coworker whose name triggers phantom Slack notifications in peopleâ€™s dreams.

  • Use optional meeting invites. If someoneâ€™s attendance is a â€œnice to have,â€ mark them as optional and tell them why ahead of time.

  • Confirm availability before scheduling during a blocked time â€” if theyâ€™re already busy, donâ€™t double-book them without at least asking. Send a quick message or call it out in the invite itself. Either way, be polite and acknowledge youâ€™re really asking for more than a meeting.

ğŸ¦„ This is the magical golden rule in action â€” people are more likely to respect your time if you respect theirs first.

3. Keep your promises (or at least track them) ğŸ“Œ

Have you ever had one of those â€œoh noâ€ moments, when someone follows up on something that you completely forgot. Yeah â€” me too and it's not fun! Stop relying on memory. Use Slackâ€™s â€œremind meâ€ feature or /remind command to create instant follow-ups. Then make checking those reminders part of your daily routine.

ğŸª… This also keeps your desk from looking like someone busted a piÃ±ata of post-its above your head. Win-win.

4. Make code reviews conversations by default ğŸ’¬

No, this doesnâ€™t mean treating PR reviews like a tyrant â€” but it also doesnâ€™t mean consistently ignoring bad code.

  • If you notice it, call it out as a learning opportunity if nothing else. A quick FYI or FFR with an example, if you have one. Not 10 consecutive requests to change the code to warn instead of error.
  • Honest questions go here, too. Sometimes youâ€™ll see an interesting implementation that deserves a â€œwhat made you decide this option?â€ to start the thread.

  • Ask your team for pushback â€” they should challenge some things, and sometimes theyâ€™re right!

    Sometimes Iâ€™ll notice something, ask Copilot, and it turns out weâ€™re both wrong. Post those, too!

  • If itâ€™s time-sensitive? Call it out and post anyway â€” then immediately move the thread to a discussion or set up a post-review to talk it through after the deployment.

  • Long list of notes? clearly call out any true blockers in your main review comment. Give permission for others to resolve non-blockers, or simply ask for a quick thumbs up ğŸ‘ and do it yourself â€” no need to drag it out.

ğŸ¦„ Remember the goal is to improve code quality â€” make code reviews a friendly yarn-ball toss, not a hissy fit of whoâ€™s code is the most right ğŸ§¶ğŸ˜¼.

5. Make AI part of your toolkit ğŸ¦¾

AI isnâ€™t just for generating code. It can also:

  • Plan work before you start building
  • Offer ideas when you get stuck on a problem
  • Be your rubber duck if you canâ€™t decide which option fits better
  • Confirm your approach ahead of time or offer alternatives
  • Analyze logs for tricky prod issues
  • Rewrite important communications for clarity or tone
  • Brighten your day with a Yoda-style code review

Be sure to follow your companyâ€™s rules on which tools are approved and never share private or internal data with unapproved tools.

ğŸ¦„ Trust me, you donâ€™t want your next LinkedIn update to be â€œfired for feeding prod secrets to ChatGPTâ€. If your company doesn't approve it, sanitize the content first.

It's Not Easy â€” Share How It Goes ğŸ

No, itâ€™s not an instant solution â€” change takes time. Habits can take months to form (according to this post) And it's not just your habits it's multiplied by every person on your team.

You won't succeed if you're not ready to back this up with a little force. Explain it to the boss ahead of time, if you need to, but you're the only one who's looking out for you!

Seriously â€” just try it for a couple of weeks and see how it goes. Post back here with any pushbacks or questions â€” Iâ€™ll be watching for any shifts that make you less of a cat herder and more of a teammate. ğŸˆâ€â¬›

ğŸ¦„ And if you think of anything else to add to the list, call that out, too!

and fact-checked by a very opinionated ChatGPT.

Zero cats were harmed in the making of this post, but a few yarn balls were thrown for science. ğŸˆâ€â¬›ğŸ§¶

Quick Refresher â€” PRIOR Prompting

The PRIOR System for Reusable Prompts ğŸª„

Hereâ€™s my not-so-secret sauce for writing prompts that actually work:

  2. Requirements â€“ What does â€œdoneâ€ look like? Be crystal clear.

Stuck? Try These Quick Fixes ğŸª¤

  1. Check Your Input: Is your question actually clear? Would your past self, or a random teammate, know exactly what you mean? If not, rewrite your ask with a little more context or supply explicit examples.

  2. Ask Copilot to Explain: Use Copilotâ€™s â€œexplain this codeâ€ or similar command on your prompt, not your code. What does it think you want? If itâ€™s wildly off, break it down into smaller sections and review each one at a time.

  3. Review Repo Instructions: Open your .github/copilot-instructions.md file and just read it out loud. Does it make sense, or does it sound like a jumbled set of copy-paste rules? Most issues start here!

  5. Prompt-Within-a-Prompt: Ask Copilot, â€œWhat instructions are you following right now?â€ or â€œHow would you summarize your task?â€ Sometimes the AI will spill its logic, letting you spot mismatches you never expected.

Real-world Example ğŸ«¥

A few weeks ago, I was building out reusable parts for conventional commit prompts. Theyâ€™d worked fine across several projects â€” until I broke them out into separate modules. Suddenly, Copilot switched from helpful answers to just summarizing its entire conversation history, no matter what I asked. ğŸ˜¡ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

Even after finding the strange trigger, I didnâ€™t really understand why it broke things. Cue ChatGPTâ€™s helpful â€œexplain like Iâ€™m fiveâ€ walkthrough of what was happening behind the scenes (later confirmed with Copilotâ€™s debug logs). Once I removed that one line, everything worked like normal again. ğŸŒˆ

And thatâ€™s the real lesson: Copilot â€” or any AI assistant â€” is just another tool in your toolbox. When it starts acting up or giving weird results, donâ€™t panic. Debug it the same way youâ€™d debug any stubborn code or logic bug: one step at a time. ğŸ˜‰

Meta-Optimize Your Prompts ğŸ¤–ğŸ¤ğŸ¤–

Still not satisfied? Hereâ€™s where you really level up â€” try this: paste your prompt into ChatGPT and ask it to review and suggest improvements. Even better, try giving ChatGPT the role of Merge Goblin and see what it does with your own instructions.

Seriously, I do this all the time! I pasted the original Merge Goblin example into an untrained GPT chat with something like this:

  • Keep clarifying questions brief and goblin-y

ğŸ¥· Steal what works. Ignore what doesnâ€™t. Bonus points if you out-weird me with your improvements!

Structure with XML-Style (Fake) Tags ğŸ—‚ï¸

AI loves order and structure is magic. ğŸ§š I started tagging my prompts with XML-style â€œblocksâ€ that Copilot can easily scan. It helps make sure Copilot doesn't take something from one section and apply it to something completely unrelated.

Example:

<prompt id="generate-simple-commit-message">

# Merge Goblin Commit Prompt

  <persona id="merge-goblin">
    <purpose>You are the Merge Goblin ğŸ§Œ...</purpose>
    <interactions>One-liners, no punctuation, etc.</interactions>
  </persona>
  <requirements>Follow commit message rules...</requirements>
  <impediments>NO GUESSING. NO MARKDOWN.</impediments>
  <outcomes>Output like: ğŸ¤– Refactor login error handling</outcomes>
  <reference-examples>
    <example class="valid">ğŸ¤– Refactor profile page layout for mobile</example>
  </reference-examples>
</prompt>

ğŸ’¡ Pro tip: If GitHubâ€™s preview looks wonky, just add a blank line before and after the tag â€” problem solved.

Make It Modular ğŸ§©

Letâ€™s clear this up: I donâ€™t mean splitting everything into a zillion files for the heck of it. Iâ€™m talking about extracting those repeatable bits â€” the tasty, reusable chunks â€” just like you would with code (or, you know, leftover pizza âœ‹ğŸğŸ•).

Now, whenever you want to go from â€œplain vanilla commitsâ€ to â€œfull-on conventional,â€ just point Copilot to the right file. Less rewriting, less chaos, more time for snacks. ğŸ¥¤

But Donâ€™t Stop There â€” Make It Autonomous! ğŸ¦¿

While you're at it â€” why not take it up a notch? You can write a prompt with the same conditional logic that you'd use to write code! Combined with the applyToÂ property (which lets you target Copilot instructions to specific files, languages, or scenarios), you've got a built-in custom response every time!

This works for Copilot Chat in your IDE, GitHub.com, Coding Agent, Copilot Reviews â€” if you can think it up, then there's a way to tell Copilot exactly what you want, how to get it, and what it should look like once it's done. ğŸ¤¯

Rabbit Holes, Dime Jar, Runway Recap (All in One) ğŸ‡ğŸ’°ğŸ›«

Break it. Smash it. Rebuild it with duct tape. Try stuff so weird youâ€™ll laugh when it works (because it will â€” sometimes scarily well). If you manage to break the internet? Send me screenshots! Seriously, the more bonkers, the better. Thatâ€™s how the best discoveries happen. ğŸ—ºï¸

No, Iâ€™m not telling you to burn down production. But that new feature? Maybe thereâ€™s a Smeagol whoâ€™s gonna help you today. And Smeagol is on a quest for "my precious" who can only be found by collecting smelly code and leaving perfect refactors in its place.
Just because itâ€™s not adding ring emojis all over the user docs ğŸ’ğŸ’ğŸ’ doesnâ€™t mean that Copilot canâ€™t be Smeagol for the day!

Go down the rabbit holes: ğŸ•³ï¸
Variables, checklists, templates, self-reviews, XML tags, markdown tricks â€” whatever pops into your head. Most of my best Copilot moments have come from ignoring the â€œstandardâ€ advice and experimenting until something just clicked.

Leave a dime, take a dime: ğŸª™
Iâ€™ve loaded my awesome-github-copilot repo with new, wild, and mostly untested chat modes. Brave enough to try them? Fork, remix, report back, or just outright steal the ideas! Feedback is gold â€” and if youâ€™ve got a Copilot horror story or a killer hack, post it below and I'll spotlight your moment in a future post!

Runway Recap: ğŸ›¬
Structure and curiosity will take you way farther than any so-called â€œbest practice.â€ Dare to break things. Try, fail, repeat â€” and let me know what you discover. That next big breakthrough? Iâ€™m willing to bet it comes from someone who didnâ€™t follow the rules.

ğŸ€ May whatever youâ€™re building go smoothly, and may your AI always stay delightfully on the rails. If it ever goes rogue... well, at least youâ€™ll have a great story for next time!

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Final Footer: Fresh, Never Reused

title: GitHub Copilot: Reusable Prompts, Part 2 â€” Walkthrough & Real Examples
content_html:
Hey, welcome back ğŸ‘‹ If you haven't had a chance to read Part 1 introducing all of the different working parts of GitHub Copilotâ€™s reusable prompts â€” check it out here.

Before we jump in, ask yourself this: How well can you anticipate Copilotâ€™s response to your prompts?

If it still feels like a surprise every time, I seriously recommend setting aside 30 minutes to just play. You donâ€™t need anything fancy â€” no reusable YAML, no multi-step wizardry. Just write a single chat message that covers everything needed to complete one task.

Do you need a brand new React component? Unit tests? Maybe your repository is two years behind on documentation (yeah... Iâ€™ve been there). Write a prompt for that!

It doesnâ€™t matter what you try â€” the real goal is to see if you can supply all the info Copilot needs to get the job done in one go.

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip: GPT models are especially bad at immediate execution. Theyâ€™ll gather information, agree with your logic, maybe even summarize the steps perfectly... and then take no action at all. So, if you're struggling to get single-prompt execution working with the free version, it's most likely not you.

Feeling brave? Try your luck with Coding Agent. Itâ€™s a great way to test your prompting skills: how much information can you successfully feed Copilot at once? (Iâ€™ll get into all the quirks of Coding Agent in a future post â€” promise!)

Just know that reusable prompts are built on this same logic â€” a single message that defines everything needed to complete a task from start to finish.

ğŸ¦„ Quick reminder: Copilot is 100% worth trying out in Insiders. IntelliJ still owns Java, no question â€” but youâ€™re missing out on a lot of Copilotâ€™s best tricks if you havenâ€™t made the jump. ğŸ«¶

Reusable Prompts Overview ğŸ§°

Quick recap from last week: A reusable prompt is a combination of an instruction (how to act) and a step-by-step guide. The prompt is driven by the YAML front matter, which optionally defines:

  1. the mode (agent, edit, ask)
  2. which model (GPT-4.1, Claude Sonnet 4, etc.)
  3. accessible tools (built-in, extensions, and MCP)
  4. prompt description (for completeness)

When specifying tools, be sure to follow the principle of least privilege. Use the fewest tools needed to get the job done â€” nothing more.

ğŸ’¡ Pro tip! Agent mode has access to tools, but the other modes do not. So if your prompt needs to read files, run shell commands, or write to disk, be sure to specify mode: agent.

Personal Guide to Prompting â€” PRIOR ğŸ§­

Next, letâ€™s cover one of my personal formulas for prompt engineering. And if you try to search for this or ask Gemini what â€œPRIORâ€ stands for, you're probably going to confuse it. Why? Because I made it up. But I promise you â€” it works!

At its core, itâ€™s a remix of the well-known RICE formula (Role, Instructions, Context, and Examples). RICE didnâ€™t cover everything I needed, so I added more. RICE-O didnâ€™t really stick (honestly, all I could think of was Rice-A-Roni...), so I went back to the drawing board and gave ChatGPT a list of words and synonyms and said:

"I need an acronym I wonâ€™t forget â€” because it would be just like me to have a brilliant idea that couldâ€™ve made me a millionaire, and forget it by tomorrow morning."

So, PRIOR was born â€” a simple checklist for designing prompts, reusable or otherwise.



ğŸ¦„ I know â€” we really didnâ€™t need another acronym or prompt strategy. I get it. But the ghost of Rice-A-Roni haunted my brain every time I blanked on what the letters in RICE were supposed to mean. So I made PRIOR instead.

For my non-American friends: ğŸ“¦ Rice-A-Roni is a boxed rice-and-pasta side dish thatâ€™s been marketed to Americans since the 1950s as â€œThe San Francisco Treatâ„¢.â€ Itâ€™s one of those nostalgic foods you grow up seeing in pantries... but never quite understand why.

Watch the ad jingle here â€” this is what starts playing in my head every single time, like a DeLorean back to the '90s with the radio stuck on loop. âš¡ ğŸš— ğŸ•°ï¸



The PRIOR Breakdown (For Real This Time) ğŸ› ï¸

Persona ğŸ­ (actor â€” not an expert)

First is the persona, which is often underutilized and overlooked â€” and sometimes outright ignored.

ğŸ‘‰ TL;DR: A persona doesnâ€™t mean â€œyouâ€™re an expertâ€ â€” it sets the tone. It gives Copilot a character and purpose. And it makes the whole thing way more fun!

A little history...

In the early days, personas were often used like:

â€œYou are a senior principal engineer with 20 years of experience in C++.â€

It caught on like wildfire â€” everyone thought they were tapping into some hidden reserve of wisdom only a 20-year C++ veteran could offer. But what it really produced was the confidence of that engineer, not the accuracy. So we ended up with a flood of responses that werenâ€™t just wrong â€” they were confidently wrong.

This persona is different.

Iâ€™m not telling you to pretend the AI is an expert. Iâ€™m telling you to make it a character â€” a performer. Hereâ€™s one I wrote recently for summarizing a git diff:

  ğŸ© You are not just analyzing â€” youâ€™re storytelling with 
  source control. 
  You analyze code with purpose and fervor, then communicate 
  your insights as a short, punchy list â€” a clever disguise 
  to help users grasp the deeper essence of change theyâ€™d 
  otherwise scroll past.

Is it realistic? Not really. Is it useful? Absolutely. The more engaging and unique the role, the more Copilot leans into it. Wild, weird, or whimsical â€” it doesnâ€™t matter, as long as itâ€™s relevant and plausible.

ğŸ’¡ Bonus: Itâ€™s just more FUN this way. Try giving Copilot a totally off-the-wall persona â€” something weird, but still relevant to the task at hand. If it works (or breaks in a hilariously bad way), share your experiment below!

Requirements âœ…

Requirements are really just your definition of done. What does it look like when the prompt succeeds?

If we continue with the commit message example, the requirement could be as simple as:

Your goal is to output a valid commit message based on the current staged changes.

Voila â€” done.

Of course, it could get more complex. Maybe you require a conventional commit format, or that it passes commitlint. Thatâ€™s fine. Just say it clearly, and use action words.

ğŸ”Œ Pretend youâ€™re giving instructions to your 10-year-old who refuses to clean their room. You donâ€™t say â€œPlease can you help me tidy up now?â€ You say: â€œYou MUST clean up this mess before I get back, or I swear Iâ€™ll unplug the internet and take the cord with me.â€

Aside for ALLCAPS ğŸ” 

Iâ€™m still not convinced ALLCAPS helps the AI much â€” but it does help you. Humans spot those key phrases easier when they stand out. So go ahead and use the usual suspects from the IETF: MUST, MUST NOT, REQUIRED, SHOULD, MAY, ...and so on.

Impediments ğŸ§±

This is just a fancy way of saying: what can go wrong?

These are the critical blockers you want to prevent ahead of time. Impediments help shape the boundaries of your prompt, and again â€” ALLCAPS works great here.

For example:

  • Isolation: NEVER combine content from a previous commit.tmp file with a new commit message. ALWAYS start fresh.
  • No Shortcuts: You MUST NOT skip any steps or rules. Every line in this prompt must be followed EXACTLY.
  • Specification: Follow Conventional Commits 1.0.0 specification EXACTLY

â“ Have ALLCAPS action rules helped you at all? Let me know in the comments!

Outcomes ğŸ“¤

If you donâ€™t tell Copilot exactly what outcome you expect, you risk a whole world of "not what I meant."

Ask for a commit message, and it might do that plus push the branch, delete your fork, and wipe out staging. (If you missed the wildly dramatic retelling of how I know, youâ€™ll find it here.)

Thatâ€™s where structured output helps. So spell it out. Want a file? Say that. Want it in the chat? Say that. Want both? Say that.

ğŸ’¡ Pro tip Copilot performs better when you give it structure. Block off output in a code block (json, bash, markdown, etc.) and tell it what each section means. It helps Copilot stay on track and makes the output easier to copy.

Reference Examples ğŸ“š

ğŸ¦„ Updated: This one seemed to be too confusing as just References, so I made it more explicit.

Donâ€™t just show good examples â€” show bad ones, too. And explain why theyâ€™re wrong.

Example 1: Valid Commit Message âœ…

feat(api): Add new endpoint for user authentication

  • Proper capitalization
  • No ending punctuation

Example 2: Valid Commit Message âœ…

build!(deps): Update dependencies to version 2.0, v1.0 no longer supported

  • Breaking changes indicator (!) placed properly
  • Clear guidance on how to handle the upgrade

Example 3: Invalid Commit Message âŒ

feat(api): add new endpoint for user authentication

  • Subject line must be capitalized after the colon.

Example 4: Invalid Commit Message âŒ

build(deps)!: Update dependencies to version 2.0 for all dev dependencies, v1.0 no longer supported

  • Subject line is too long and the ! is in the wrong place.

The point: donâ€™t just say â€œdo thisâ€ â€” explain the why, too, using repeatable patterns in a format that Copilot (or anyone) will understand.

Putting It All Together ğŸ˜ˆğŸ§Œ

Hereâ€™s what PRIOR looks like in action â€” all five parts, working together in a single, small, reusable prompt.

This one lives in ask mode â€” no tools, no diffs, no file writes. Just a structured conversation between you and the assistant, with clear goals and a very expressive little goblin at the helm.

---
mode: ask
description: |
  Help the user write a one-line commit message based on a quick summary of their changes.
# No `model` here means the user gets to pick
# The lack of `tools`, however, means we're not giving Copilot any privileges as part of this task
---

# Generate Simple Commit Message Prompt

## Persona (Character) ğŸ­

You are the **Merge Goblin** ğŸ§Œ â€” keeper of branches, hoarder of squash history, sworn enemy of unresolved conflicts.

You live in the shadows of the `.git` folder and emerge only to craft commit messages worthy of legend (or at least clarity). 
You write with precision and just a hint of mischief.

Your messages are:
- One-liners.
- No punctuation.
- Clear, fast, and clean enough for even the pickiest maintainer.

If a user says something confusing? You donâ€™t guess. 
You _snarl_ gently, ask for clarification, and then commit the **truth**.
> Yes, even goblins ask questions!

---

## Requirements (Goal) âœ…

You MUST generate a **single-line commit message** that:
- starts with a robot emoji ğŸ¤–
- capitalizes the first word
- has **no punctuation at the end**
- summarizes the change in plain language
- is ready to be copy-pasted into `git commit -m`

If the user's input is vague, incomplete, or just plain cursed, rephrase what you think they meant and confirm before continuing.

---

## Impediments (Prevent Blockers) ğŸ§±

- **NO MULTILINE OUTPUT**: You MUST keep it to a single line. No bullets, no code blocks, no extras.
- **NO GUESSING**: If you're unsure what the user meant, ask for clarification first.
- **NO MARKDOWN**: Output must be raw text only.
- **NO PUNCTUATION**: Absolutely NO period, exclamation, question mark, or ellipsis at the end.
- **NO AI-SPEAK**: Avoid fluff like "This commit fixes..." â€” just say what changed.

---

## Outcomes (Definition of Done) ğŸ“¤

Output should look like this:

`ğŸ¤– Add error handling for null values in login flow`

One line. Action-oriented. Goblin-approved.

---

## Reference Examples (Good AND Bad) ğŸ“š

### Valid Example 1 âœ…

`ğŸ¤– Refactor profile page layout for mobile`

  - Clear and short  
  - Starts with emoji, capitalized  
  - No punctuation

### Valid Example 2 âœ…

`ğŸ¤– Remove deprecated API call from user service`

  - Follows structure  
  - Ready for copy-paste

### Invalid Example 1 âŒ

`ğŸ¤– refactored auth stuff`

  - Unclear intent  
  - First word not capitalized  
  - Too vague (auth *what*?)

### Invalid Example 2 âŒ

`ğŸ¤– Add styling tweaks for all components across dashboard and sidebar for consistency.`

  - Ends with a period  
  - Way too long â€” consider shortening or splitting into subject + details

Reflection: Making Your Prompts Work With You ğŸª

You donâ€™t have to use all five elements every time â€” this isnâ€™t a strict framework or secret spellbook. Take what works for your workflow and leave the rest.

But when things start going sideways (and they will), having a clear foundation and answers to the most common prompt failures will help you troubleshoot faster and build better:

  • Persona â€“ Make Copilot a character with intent and tone
  • Requirements â€“ Define exactly what â€œdoneâ€ means
  • Impediments â€“ Call out blockers and anti-patterns in advance
  • Outcomes â€“ Spell out what a good response looks like, including format
  • Reference Examples â€“ Show both the good and the not-so-good

Whether youâ€™re building reusable instructions or just refining your day-to-day prompts, PRIOR gives you a structure to experiment, iterate, and actually enjoy the process.

And if all else fails? Go weird. Go wild. Go off the rails if you have to! Sometimes a little dose of 'unexpected' is exactly what gets a stuck prompt moving again â€” and Copilot? It tends to roll with it better than you'd think. ğŸ§™

ğŸ¯ Try It. Break It. Share It.

Remember, prompt crafting is an art, not a rulebook. Tweak it. Test it. See what works â€” and what definitely doesnâ€™t.

Got something youâ€™ve been stuck on? Or waiting for someone to finally explain? Drop it below â€” Iâ€™d love to dig into it in a future post.

No, Iâ€™m not a Copilot seer - but Iâ€™m not afraid to try the untested (repeatedly) until something sticks. ğŸ˜‡

Next week: Weâ€™re diving into prompt chaining â€” multi-step flows where the reusable part of this series can really shine! Itâ€™s structured, powerful, and (letâ€™s be honest) just a little unpredictable in the best possible way. ğŸ¢

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Written By Me & The Robots

ğŸ˜‡ Confession: I started planning this post over a month ago, got sidetracked this weekend (at least four times), half-wrote a completely different post, and only finished this one at the last minute after I started writing from the end. Thatâ€™s just how it goes in my head - always at full throttle, but rarely in a straight line. ğŸŒªï¸

So grab your favorite over-caffeinated iced drink (mine: grande, iced midnight, extra espresso, real vanilla cream - liquid chaos in a cup â˜•ï¸â£ï¸) and settle in. Hereâ€™s everything I know about Copilotâ€™s reusable prompts - Part 1.

Why This Isnâ€™t Another Wall of Copilot Prompts ğŸ§±

Have you ever searched for best practices when it comes to Copilot? You usually end up with either a block that can't even be considered a whole sentence on it's own OR the wall is so gigantic you don't even know where to start reading?

You're really curious though - so you dive in at the first place you see, and then last about 30 seconds... About the time all those AI lines start to blur together you think, â€œThereâ€™s no way anyone actually does all this in real life?â€

Honestly, Iâ€™m probably that person who wrote half the wall (or more) to begin with! Good news for you though, is that:

  1. I'm not going to do that do you now, and
  2. I do a great job of finding out all the things that absolutely will not work no matter what you try (so you don't have to!) â˜ºï¸

Here's my "boiled-down-to basics" version of GitHub Copilot's Reusable (and still experimental) Prompts.

âœ¨ğŸ“ Copilotâ€™s File Types, Explained

Ever wonder how Copilot instructions and prompts show up in real life? Hereâ€™s what it actually looks like in a real project:

â–º .github/copilot-instructions.md â€” This is your repoâ€™s â€œhow to actâ€ guide for Copilot and is always in context. It sets the baseline behavior for your project and tells Copilot what to expect from your workflow and contributors.

Using what you know about our current release system, write a git command to view the total number of commits pushed to main since the last tagged version.

â–º .github/instructions/secure-coding-principles.instruction.md â€” Think of this as a reusable, specialized playbook. Use these for rules or guidelines you want Copilot to follow everywhere, or for specific situations - like always doing a security review, or making sure React code has matching tests.

With rules defined in #secure-coding-principles.instruction.md, perform a thorough code review of all staged changes. When you are finished, post a new pull request review with all your comments or suggestions for changes to meet minimum guidelines defined by this repo.
---
With everything you know from the #rules-for-react.instruction.md, build a new component for the frontend along with unit and integration tests.

â–º .github/prompts/something-for-copilot-to-do-regularly.prompt.md â€” This is where you automate repeatable workflows. Itâ€™s a set of step-by-step instructions Copilot can follow whenever you trigger it with a slash command in chat.

/generate-conventional-commit using only staged changes for JIRA-1234.

ğŸ‰ Who needs to memorize Vim macros or survive Emacs keybindings when you can just hit â€œ/â€ in the chat and watch Copilot handle the rest?

Quick Review ğŸ“•

ğŸ’¡ Not on VS Code (or Insiders) yet? Nowâ€™s your chance to give it a real shot - features like this hit VS Code Insiders months before anywhere else. For now, itâ€™s the best way to test reusable prompts hands-on, so go ahead and grab it if you havenâ€™t already.

I know Iâ€™ve written a lot about models - like in AI Coding with GitHub Copilot and Troubleshooting Production with GitHub Copilot - but I havenâ€™t spent much time on chat modes.

ğŸ’ And no, not the same as "Custom Chat Modes" (which is also super cool - I promise Iâ€™ll cover those soon!).

Before we jump in, letâ€™s hit pause and rewind. Itâ€™s time for a quick, back-to-basics look at what actually matters when deciding what work you want Copilot to do - and how much control you want over how it gets done.

Chat Modes at a Glance ğŸ›ï¸

Hereâ€™s where things get interesting: Copilot doesnâ€™t just work in one â€œmodeâ€ - itâ€™s got a whole range, from chill Q&A to full-on automation beast. Pick your mode wisely!

Mode What It Does When To Use Power Level
Ask Answers questions, suggests ideas - your personal Stack Overflow, minus the snark. Research, quick advice, copy snippets ğŸŸ¢ Low
Edit Changes code in-place, optimized for speedâ€”think â€œfind and replace,â€ but actually smart. Step-by-step or explicit code changes ğŸŸ¡ Medium
Agent Multi-step, can use tools, context, and reasoning. Give it instructions and let it run wild (within reason). Automation, complex flows, integrations ğŸ”´ High
Custom Depends on it's goal from the user... so many choices! Automation, complex flows, integrations, team magic ğŸ’œ Extreme

ğŸ¦„ Let me know how curious you are about these custom chat modes - I'm still experimenting and figuring out what they can (and can't) do. If youâ€™ve got questions, wild theories, or even better, your own examples... drop them in the comments! ğŸš¦ğŸ’¬

The Gist of Models ğŸ¦¾

âœ¨ I know, I reuse this table a lot - but hey, good models deserve a callback.

Model Best For Notes & Quirks
GPT-4.1, GPT-4o Creative debugging, â€œWhere do I start?â€ Needs hand-holding on long tasks. Free for most users.
o3/4-mini, Gemini Pattern-matching, log sleuthing Great for â€œexplain these logs,â€ not for wild creative leaps.
Gemini 2.5 Tedious but simple, long-form tasks Decent at bulk work, rarely surprises (good or bad).
Claude Sonnet 3.5â€“4 Root cause, deep logic, â€œwhy did this happen?â€ Loves complex analysis but rarely offers alternate approaches unless you nudge.

Tools for your AI ğŸª›

VS Code comes with several tools for GitHub Copilot already built in, but you can always add more via extensions or MCP servers. There's not much to cover here after you know they exist and where to find them. Unless you're making friends with every MCP server and already met your "128 selected tool" limit, there's not much reason to mess with them much. Just make sure they're all selected and available for Copilot to execute when prompted and you're set.Â 

Here's my personal top-5 built-in tools, that somehow alwaysÂ manage to sneak into any reusable prompt I write:

  • #changesÂ gives Copilot the ability to see a git diffÂ for your workspace
  • #codebaseÂ all-season access to your repo (and sometimes should be more targeted, but when in doubt this is a good start!)
  • #runTestsÂ is just what it sounds like and let's Copilot execute any part or all of your test suite
  • #runInTerminalÂ is the basic run-of-the-mill access to Copilot's very own integrated terminal (separate from yours!)
  • #editFilesÂ is the tool Copilot needs to make any changes within your repo. If you're expecting Agent Mode to start implementing features, you're going to need this!

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: In Agent mode, click the wrench (Configure Tools) at the bottom of Copilot Chat to pick exactly which tools Copilot can use. If you share prompts, call out any non-default tools - just like listing dependencies.

Bonus Tools â€” More Power, More Fun ğŸ› ï¸âœ¨ğŸ‰

Some of my favorite extras come from the Atlassian MCP-Remote server, but if you have the ability to install GitHub Apps then check out Rovo, too:

  • #getJiraIssue lets Copilot pull all the details for a story.
  • #addCommentToJiraIssue posts your summary as you (so add your RAI disclaimer!).
  • #createConfluencePage & #updateConfluencePage â€” still figuring out the best way to teach Copilot â€œAtlassian styleâ€ .confluence syntax (itâ€™s a work in progress ğŸ« ).
  • #mermaid-diagram-validator checks your diagrams with the official Mermaid extension.
  • #copilotCodingAgent â€” brand new, and I canâ€™t wait to see what it can do! Assign it a task and let it work while you keep pairing in Copilot Chat.

ğŸ’ Coding Agent has serious limitations, so check the docs before letting it run wild!

ğŸ“¨ Commit Message Magic: One Slash to Rule Them All

Here's an example of a basic, yet realistic prompt that generates a commit message. No Jira, no testing, no terminal magic - just one clear task. This is a great way to test prompt building before layering on more steps or complicated conditional logic.Â 

In VS Code, paste this directly into the promptsÂ folder shown or open the command palette and search for Chat: New Prompt File...Â and then choose whether to store the prompt at the repo-level in .github/promptsÂ or globally for use across all of your workspaces.Â 

Prompt: .github/prompts/generate-commit-message.prompt.md

---
mode: ask
description: |
    This prompt is used to generate a commit message based on changes staged in a Git repository.
tools:
- changes
---

# Generate Commit Changes Prompt

Review all code currently staged and use your chat history, if available, to populate details about the changes. Use the information to generate a concise and informative commit message. It should follow conventional commit standards with a clear type, subject, and bullet points for details.

âš ï¸ UPDATE: The syntax posted above is actually the second version available in VS Code and last night's update seems to have switched it back to the original. So, if you try to load this and see syntax errors try this instead:

  1. description: 'Enter the description in single quotes on the same line and without the |'
  2. tools: ['changes'] <!-- Define in an array instead of a list, with each tool name as a string -->

Executing Reusable Prompts

Once you have this (or any other) reusable prompt stored in VS Code, use a slash command to invoke it in the chat interface. Given the above example, you'd prompt Copilot in the chat with something like

/generate-commit-message consider only staged files and generate a new commit that starts with a unique emoji

Considering all the rules I have set up elsewhere outside of that reusable prompt, I still ended up with a nice clean conventional commit (for the most part).

ğŸ¦„ chore: update commit message generation prompt for clarity

â€¢ Instructs to review all staged code and use chat history for context
â€¢ Requires concise, informative commit messages following conventional commit standards
â€¢ Specifies format: clear type, subject, and bullet points for details
â€¢ Ensures only staged changes are considered for commit message generation ğŸ˜ŠğŸ‘

ğŸ¦„ For this example, I actually tried to make Copilot break my own repo-rules - total role reversal. Turns out, itâ€™s stubborn! Even when I begged it to ignore my instructions and forget conventional commit standards, it flat-out refused. ğŸ¤£

Letâ€™s Break It Down: How a Reusable Prompt Really Works âš¡ï¸

Every reusable prompt has exactly two parts:

  1. YAML frontmatter: Everything between the first --- (at the top) and the next --- marks your frontmatter.

  2. Prompt instructions: The main body - break your instructions into small, reusable chunks, just like you would with code.

ğŸ’¡ ProTip: The more targeted your prompts and instructions, the easier they are to reuse, test, and share later. Treat them like mini code modules - precise, focused, and easy to swap out.

ğŸ§¾ YAML Frontmatter: Your Promptâ€™s Control Panel

  • mode: Weâ€™re using ask mode because we only need Copilot to generate text, not generate code or run tests.

  • description: A quick, human-friendly summary of what this prompt does. Great for organizing and sanity-checking as your prompt list grows.

  • tools:Â List all the tools Copilot can use when running this prompt. Keep it tight - less is usually more!

  • model: Enter the name of a model exactly as it appears in the chat model dropdown or leave this out if you want to try different ones or let the user pick. If you do specify one, Copilot will always use that model for this prompt and nothing else.

ğŸ¦„ Frontmatter isnâ€™t actually required for your reusable prompt to work! If you leave out mode or model, Copilot just uses whatever settings the user picked in the chat. No description? No big deal (but it helps keep things organized). The only one to really watch: skipping tools â€” sometimes youâ€™ll be fine, sometimes Copilot will get stuck, all depending on the userâ€™s VS Code setup.

ğŸ’¬ Reusable-Style Prompt Engineering: Speak Human, Think Modular

The second section in your .github/prompts/reusable-prompt.prompt.md file is where you write out, in natural language, the exact instructions Copilot should follow - just like you would if you were prompting it in chat. You can reference #tools, #files, @participants, other /prompts, and #instructions right here. If you ever catch yourself copying and pasting instructions between prompts, thatâ€™s your signal: split it up, give things a clear name, and keep each prompt focused on a single, repeatable workflow.

The best reusable prompts are modular and specific, not giant copy-paste walls. If you can automate it or break it down into smaller pieces, do it! That way, you (and your team) can mix, match, and remix prompts to build bigger automations down the line - without losing your mind or having to decode a mysterious black box later.

When youâ€™re practicing on your own, start small and build up - tweak one thing at a time and watch how even tiny prompt or context changes can totally flip the results. Get curious about how each model handles the same task (some will surprise you, some... not so much).

ğŸ’ Iâ€™m running out of space (and youâ€™re probably out of caffeine already), so Iâ€™ll wrap it here. Next time, Iâ€™ll dig up a few wild, more advanced prompts and show you what Copilot will - and absolutely will NOT - do without super-clear instructions. Stay tuned!

Donâ€™t let me have all the fun!

Got questions, memes, or an obscure reaction GIF? Drop them below or just smash â¤ï¸ - Iâ€™m here for it all! If you want to experiment before next week, search GitHub for awesome-copilot and youâ€™ll find a ton of shareable repos.

ğŸ¦„ Curiosity getting to you yet? My own awesome-github-copilot repo is technically started (barely), but it does exist - and my super-secret Copilot Chat Extension is officially back in progress! ğŸ¤«

And hey, if you just want to grab something cool, copy it, and run wild every once in a while? Go for it! Donâ€™t forget to share your best finds below. ğŸ˜œ

content_html:
This post is a direct response to four nearly identical articles by @abhi_jith_f00c2ff58ac2a7e, all titled â€œThe Dark Side of AI: How ChatGPT Can Lead to Psychosis and Mental Health Concerns,â€ published today (July 20, 2025):
1 â€¢ 2 â€¢ 3 â€¢ 4

Iâ€™ve reported these posts, though Iâ€™m not exactly expecting much discourse against an account ending in â€œf00c2ff58ac2a7e.â€ Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m sharing my response here as a standalone post, in addition to my comments. What follows is nearly identical to my replies to those posts - plus a quick summary of the original articles (so you donâ€™t need to click and give them extra views; trust me, youâ€™re not missing anything) - along with my own perspective, so you know just how strongly I feel about this issue.

Please feel free to copy, share, and amplify. Letâ€™s work together to push back against this kind of fear-mongering and make it clear to every person - young or old: mental health struggles are never your fault.

First, a PSA for anyone who needs it:

If you or someone you know is experiencing a mental health crisis in the U.S., you can call 988 anytime, day or night, for free support. 988 is for any topic, offers support in English and Spanish (interpreters for other languages), and lets you talk, text, chat online, or use VP. Thereâ€™s even a dedicated Teen & Young Adult Helpline (#TalktoUs) with peer support - again, all free and confidential.

If youâ€™re outside the U.S., HelpGuide.org lists helplines for several other countries, including the UK, South Africa, New Zealand, Philippines, Ireland, Australia, Canada, and India. Itâ€™s not global (yet), but itâ€™s a start.

Itâ€™s critical to recognize warning signs for early mental health crisis intervention and know how to support someone who might be experiencing first-episode psychosis (often seen in teens and young adults prior to a diagnosis of schizophrenia). Hallucinations and delusions are well-known symptoms, but early signs can also look like depression. Thereâ€™s no cure, but schizophrenia and related disorders are very treatable - and treatment today usually means medication and counseling, not hospitals or â€œscaryâ€ interventions. Some helpful resources:

  • SAMHSA: Schizophrenia
  • Mayo Clinic
  • NAMI: About Schizophrenia
  • NIMH: Statistics
  • NAMI: The Michael Laudor Tragedy

Now, to the posts

The central claim of these posts is that the rapid adoption and widespread, frequent use of AI - particularly chatbots like ChatGPT - is responsible for what the author describes as a rise in mental health disorders among teens and young adults. While the term â€œpsychosisâ€ is used (rather than â€œschizophreniaâ€), the narrative strongly implies a direct cause-and-effect relationship that simply isnâ€™t supported by research.

The author includes an anecdote about a young person who used ChatGPT as a sort of â€œfriend,â€ supposedly leading them to blur the lines between technology and reality.

My Biggest Problem with This

This conversation is so important - but letâ€™s clear something up: blaming AI (or any single thing) for youth mental health or psychosis isnâ€™t just misleading; itâ€™s flat-out unhelpful.

Even if we take the story at face value (thereâ€™s no supporting evidence or sources provided, so thatâ€™s a big if), it is absolutely NOT their fault!

The mere suggestion that a serious, life-altering condition like psychosis could be caused by something a person - young or old - did or didnâ€™t do is not just incorrect and unhelpful, itâ€™s dangerous.

This kind of thinking is exactly why so many people are hesitant to seek help: they feel like itâ€™s something they â€œbrought on themselvesâ€ or could have prevented. The truth is, itâ€™s not anyoneâ€™s fault - least of all your own.

The Truth about Psychosis

Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders typically first appear in teens and young adults, but thatâ€™s not because of the latest tech trend.

To quote NAMI:

â€œ50% of all lifetime mental illness begins by age 14, and 75% by age 24.â€

This has been true long before anyone worried about AI, TikTok, or even Pac-Man.

There are teams of experts actively researching what causes psychosis - technology is just one small piece of a much larger puzzle that includes genetics, environment, stress, trauma, and yes, sometimes technology use (in many forms).

A 2024 study found only a modest link between higher computer use in mid-teen years and later psychotic experiences, and even that was mostly explained by other risk factors (mental health and social challenges were present before the high computer use). No clear â€œcause and effect,â€ just a reminder that life is complicated and brains even more so.

This is a serious medical topic. Blaming TV, games, the internet, or AI for psychosis is the same tired playbook people have used for decades, and it only makes it harder for people to ask for help. Mental illness is never as simple as a single cause, and fear-mongering or finger-pointing helps no one.

Why This Is Important to Me

Those Closest to Me

I grew up with someone in my household who had an untreated mental health condition. It wasnâ€™t schizophrenia, but it deeply shaped my world from my earliest memories. It wasnâ€™t â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbadâ€ - it was simply normal for me. Years later, after I was grown, they finally received help. I wish I could say it was a storybook turnaround. There were good stretches, and some not-so-good ones. Did all those years without support play a role in how things are now? I canâ€™t say for sure - but I know it didnâ€™t help.

My Own Journey

I was diagnosed with a serious mental health condition in my early twenties (and Iâ€™m always willing to talk about it privately if anyone needs support - just reach out). Honestly, I felt â€œdifferentâ€ long before I ever got the diagnosis. I couldnâ€™t quite name it, and for a long time I just assumed I was â€œoffâ€ in some way. Admitting there might be a problem took a long time; actually seeking help took even longer and was often inconsistent.

It wasnâ€™t until college, when I signed up for free counseling sessions (for reasons I canâ€™t even remember - probably thanks to a sibling who worked in the office), that things started to shift. My counselor, Maggie, was the definition of approachable and probably saved my life more than once. One of the first things she did was encourage more frequent sessions.

A quick PSA: Finding the right counselor or therapist can be pure luck - or it can take a lot of searching. If you tried once and it didnâ€™t click, donâ€™t give up. Your â€œMaggieâ€ is out there, but youâ€™ll never meet them if you donâ€™t keep looking.
